verses.text: Paul came to Derbe and then to Lystra, where there was a disciple named Timothy, the son of a believing Jewish woman, but his father was Greek.
verses.comment: Timothy's mixed heritage highlights the openness of the early Church to all cultures, both Jews and Gentiles. The faith was passed on by his mother, showing the deep importance of family tradition in handing down faith.

verses.text: The believers in Lystra and Iconium spoke highly of him.
verses.comment: Timothy’s reputation among local Christians prepares the way for his role in leadership. He is recognized by established communities before being sent out, similar to how the early Church was careful in appointing leaders.

verses.text: Paul wanted Timothy to accompany him, and took him and circumcised him because of the Jews in those areas, for they all knew that his father was Greek.
verses.comment: Though the Council at Jerusalem didn't require circumcision (Acts 15), Paul circumcises Timothy for the sake of ministry among Jews. This shows a pastoral approach valuing unity and the ability to minister effectively to diverse people.

verses.text: As they traveled through the cities, they delivered the decisions reached by the apostles and elders in Jerusalem to be observed.
verses.comment: Paul and Timothy carry apostolic decrees, showing the structure and authority of apostolic leadership handed down from Jerusalem—a model for orderly governance in the Church.

verses.text: So the churches were strengthened in the faith and grew in numbers daily.
verses.comment: Growth in faith and numbers comes as the Church adheres to apostolic teaching and unity. This emphasizes the importance of doctrinal fidelity and communal worship.

verses.text: They passed through the region of Phrygia and Galatia, being prevented by the Holy Spirit from speaking the word in Asia.
verses.comment: The Holy Spirit actively directs missionary work, guiding the Church and showing divine initiative.

verses.text: When they came to Mysia, they tried to go into Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus did not allow them.
verses.comment: 'Spirit of Jesus' reinforces Christ's ongoing presence and guidance of the Church, signifying that Jesus is divine and active.

verses.text: So, passing by Mysia, they went down to Troas.
verses.comment: Troas becomes the launching point for the Gospel advancing west—a pivotal moment in salvation history.

verses.text: During the night Paul had a vision: a man from Macedonia was standing and appealing to him, 'Come over to Macedonia and help us.'
verses.comment: God uses supernatural means to direct the Church’s mission, providentially expanding the Gospel to new lands as Christ continues to shepherd His people.

verses.text: After Paul had seen the vision, immediately we tried to leave for Macedonia, concluding that God had called us to preach the Gospel to them.
verses.comment: The shift to the plural 'we' indicates Luke joins the journey. Apostolic cooperation and responsiveness to divine calling are essential features of the Church.

verses.text: So, setting sail from Troas, we made a direct voyage to Samothrace, and the next day to Neapolis.
verses.comment: Precise travel details reflect Luke’s historical accuracy and eyewitness testimony.

verses.text: From there to Philippi, a leading city of that district of Macedonia and a Roman colony. We remained in that city for several days.
verses.comment: Philippi’s importance sets the stage for the founding of the first church in Europe. Roman law shapes local customs and the context for preaching the Gospel.

verses.text: On the Sabbath day we went outside the city gate to the riverside, where we thought there would be a place of prayer. We sat down and spoke to the women who had gathered there.
verses.comment: Gathering for prayer outside the city gate shows faith’s persistence even where no synagogue exists. Women take a leading role in receiving the Gospel.

verses.text: A woman named Lydia, a seller of purple cloth from the city of Thyatira, who worshipped God, was listening. The Lord opened her heart to pay attention to what Paul was saying.
verses.comment: Lydia's conversion is enabled by God’s grace, hinting at the doctrine of prevenient grace. Her leadership demonstrates early examples of household faith.

verses.text: After she and her household were baptized, she invited us, saying, 'If you have judged me faithful to the Lord, come and stay at my house.' And she persuaded us.
verses.comment: The immediate baptism of her and her household hints at the practice of family faith and possibly infant baptism. Hospitality among believers strengthens the Church’s unity and mission.

verses.text: As we were going to the place of prayer, a slave girl who had a spirit of divination met us. She brought her owners much profit by fortune-telling.
verses.comment: Spiritual opposition parallels earlier events in Acts. The girl’s exploitation contrasts with Christ’s liberation.

verses.text: She followed Paul and us, shouting, 'These men are servants of the Most High God, who proclaim to you the way of salvation!'
verses.comment: Spirits recognize divine authority, but their testimony is not accepted, echoing Christ’s refusal of demonic witness.

verses.text: She kept this up for many days. Paul, annoyed, turned and said to the spirit, 'I command you in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her.' And it came out at that very moment.
verses.comment: Paul exercises miraculous authority through Christ’s name, showing continuity with Jesus’ ministry and the power granted to His Apostles.

verses.text: But when her owners saw their hope of profit was gone, they seized Paul and Silas and dragged them into the marketplace before the authorities.
verses.comment: Economic interests resist the Gospel’s freeing power. The apostolic mission regularly challenges societal injustices.

verses.text: When they had brought them to the magistrates, they said, 'These men are disturbing our city. They are Jews.'
verses.comment: Accusations against the apostles reflect suspicion toward believers and foreshadow later persecutions.

verses.text: 'They advocate customs that are not lawful for us Romans to accept or practice.'
verses.comment: The challenge to Roman customs shows the counter-cultural nature of Christianity and its call to a higher law.

verses.text: The crowd joined in attacking them, and the magistrates ordered them to be stripped and beaten with rods.
verses.comment: Public persecution of believers for the faith was a common challenge faced by the apostles.

verses.text: After inflicting many blows, they threw them into prison, charging the jailer to keep them securely.
verses.comment: Apostolic suffering anticipates the sacrificial witness required of all believers.

verses.text: Having received such strict orders, he put them into the inner cell and fastened their feet in the stocks.
verses.comment: Maximum security attempts to prevent any escape, foreshadowing a coming divine intervention.

verses.text: About midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the other prisoners were listening to them.
verses.comment: Praying and singing in suffering recalls the Psalms and liturgical worship, showing the importance of communal prayer even in hardship.

verses.text: Suddenly there was a great earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison were shaken; immediately all the doors were opened and everyone’s chains were unfastened.
verses.comment: God uses miraculous signs to liberate His servants and affirm His power over earthly constraints.

verses.text: When the jailer woke and saw the prison doors open, he drew his sword and was about to kill himself, thinking the prisoners had escaped.
verses.comment: Roman law demanded severe punishment for jailers who lost prisoners; the jailer’s response reveals his sense of responsibility.

verses.text: But Paul cried out with a loud voice, 'Do not harm yourself, for we are all here!'
verses.comment: Paul’s concern for the jailer demonstrates the charity that marks Christlike behavior. Mercy offered even to one’s oppressor is a witness to redemption.

verses.text: The jailer called for lights, rushed in, and trembling with fear, fell down before Paul and Silas.
verses.comment: The jailer’s posture foreshadows repentance and submission to the Gospel.

verses.text: Then he brought them out and asked, 'Sirs, what must I do to be saved?'
verses.comment: Profoundly aware of his need, the jailer asks about salvation. The apostles are the authoritative source for the answer, reflecting apostolic teaching's centrality.

verses.text: They said, 'Believe in the Lord Jesus and you will be saved—you and your household.'
verses.comment: Salvation is offered through faith in Jesus, but household inclusion again hints at communal participation in the Church and baptism for all family members.

verses.text: And they spoke the word of the Lord to him and to all who were in his house.
verses.comment: The whole household is catechized before baptism—preaching comes before sacramental action, showing the importance of instruction in the faith.

verses.text: At that hour of the night, he took them and washed their wounds; then immediately he and all his family were baptized.
verses.comment: Immediate baptism after instruction illustrates the urgency of entering the Church, and the entire family’s participation continues the theme of household conversion.

verses.text: Then he brought them into his house, set food before them, and rejoiced because he and his entire household had believed in God.
verses.comment: Joy and hospitality after conversion are marks of new life in Christ. Fellowship around a meal echoes the communal nature of Christian worship.

verses.text: When it was day, the magistrates sent their officers, saying, 'Release those men.'
verses.comment: The authorities, seeing no further reason to detain them, order their release. God’s intervention brings about justice.

verses.text: The jailer reported this to Paul: 'The magistrates have sent word to release you. So come out now and go in peace.'
verses.comment: Divine deliverance is followed by a peaceful dismissal, modeled after Christ’s peace imparted to His disciples.

verses.text: But Paul said to them, 'They have beaten us publicly, without a trial, men who are Roman citizens, and have thrown us into prison. Do they now want to send us away secretly? No. Let them come themselves and escort us out.'
verses.comment: Paul invokes his rights as a Roman citizen, asserting justice and integrity. Apostles stand for truth and dignity, both spiritually and socially.

verses.text: The officers told the magistrates these words, and they were afraid when they heard that they were Roman citizens.
verses.comment: Fear results from mistreating citizens. The world recognizes the dignity instilled in believers.

verses.text: So they came and apologized to them. Then, bringing them out, they asked them to leave the city.
verses.comment: Humility is required even from those in authority towards the apostles. The Church endures persecution but remains dignified through grace.

verses.text: After leaving the prison, they went to Lydia’s house, where they saw and encouraged the brothers. Then they departed.
verses.comment: The early believers gathered for encouragement, reflecting the continuous need for communal worship, apostolic teaching, and brotherly support in the life of faith.
